segments.en: Numbered Discourses 3
4. Messengers from the Gods
40. In Charge
“There are, mendicants, these three things to put in charge.
What three?
Putting oneself, the world, or the teaching in charge.
And what, mendicants, is putting oneself in charge?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

segments.pli: ‘na kho panāhaṃ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
segments.en: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,

segments.pli: Na piṇḍapātahetu, na senāsanahetu, na itibhavābhavahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
segments.en: alms-food, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.

segments.pli: Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto.
segments.en: But I was swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I was swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

segments.pli: Appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethāti.
segments.en: And I thought, “Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.”

segments.pli: Ahañceva kho pana yādisake kāme ohāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito tādisake vā kāme pariyeseyyaṃ tato vā pāpiṭṭhatare, na metaṃ patirūpan’ti.
segments.en: But it would not be appropriate for me to seek sensual pleasures like those I abandoned when I went forth, or even worse.’
Then they reflect:

segments.pli: ‘āraddhaṃ kho pana me vīriyaṃ bhavissati asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggan’ti.
segments.en: ‘My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be immersed in samādhi.’

segments.pli: So attānaṃyeva adhipatiṃ karitvā akusalaṃ pajahati, kusalaṃ bhāveti, sāvajjaṃ pajahati, anavajjaṃ bhāveti, suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharati.
segments.en: Putting themselves in charge, they give up the unskillful and develop the skillful, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.
This is called putting oneself in charge.
And what, mendicants, is putting the world in charge?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

segments.pli: ‘na kho panāhaṃ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
segments.en: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,

segments.pli: Na piṇḍapātahetu, na senāsanahetu, na itibhavābhavahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
segments.en: alms-food, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.

segments.pli: Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto.
segments.en: But I was swamped by rebirth, old age, and death, by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I was swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

segments.pli: Appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
segments.en: And I thought, “Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.”

segments.pli: Ahañceva kho pana evaṃ pabbajito samāno kāmavitakkaṃ vā vitakkeyyaṃ, byāpādavitakkaṃ vā vitakkeyyaṃ, vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ vā vitakkeyyaṃ, mahā kho panāyaṃ lokasannivāso.
segments.en: And now, since I’ve now gone forth, I might have sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts. But the population of the world is large,

segments.pli: Mahantasmiṃ kho pana lokasannivāse santi samaṇabrāhmaṇā iddhimanto dibbacakkhukā paracittaviduno.
segments.en: and there are ascetics and brahmins who have psychic power—they’re clairvoyant, and can read the minds of others.

segments.pli: Te dūratopi passanti, āsannāpi na dissanti, cetasāpi cittaṃ pajānanti.
segments.en: They see far without being seen, even by those close; and they understand the minds of others.
They would know me:

segments.pli: ‘passatha, bho, imaṃ kulaputtaṃ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno vokiṇṇo viharati pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehī’ti.
segments.en: “Look at this gentleman; they’ve gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, but they’re living mixed up with bad, unskillful qualities.”

segments.pli: devatāpi kho santi iddhimantiniyo dibbacakkhukā paracittaviduniyo.
segments.en: And there are deities, too, who have psychic power—they’re clairvoyant, and can read the minds of others.

segments.pli: Tā dūratopi passanti, āsannāpi na dissanti, cetasāpi cittaṃ jānanti.
segments.en: They see far without being seen, even by those close; and they understand the minds of others.
They would know me:

segments.pli: ‘passatha, bho, imaṃ kulaputtaṃ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito samāno vokiṇṇo viharati pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehī’ti.
segments.en: “Look at this gentleman; they’ve gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, but they’re living mixed up with bad, unskillful qualities.”’
Then they reflect:

segments.pli: ‘āraddhaṃ kho pana me vīriyaṃ bhavissati asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggan’ti.
segments.en: ‘My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be immersed in samādhi.’

segments.pli: So lokaṃyeva adhipatiṃ karitvā akusalaṃ pajahati, kusalaṃ bhāveti, sāvajjaṃ pajahati, anavajjaṃ bhāveti, suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharati.
segments.en: Putting the world in charge, they give up the unskillful and develop the skillful, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.
This is called putting the world in charge.
And what, mendicants, is putting the teaching in charge?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

segments.pli: ‘na kho panāhaṃ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
segments.en: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,

segments.pli: Na piṇḍapātahetu, na senāsanahetu, na itibhavābhavahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
segments.en: alms-food, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.

segments.pli: Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto.
segments.en: But I was swamped by rebirth, old age, and death, by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I was swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.

segments.pli: Appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethāti.
segments.en: And I thought, “Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.”

segments.pli: Svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhīti.
segments.en: The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

segments.pli: Santi kho pana me sabrahmacārī jānaṃ passaṃ viharanti.
segments.en: I have spiritual companions who live knowing and seeing.

segments.pli: Ahañceva kho pana evaṃ svākkhāte dhammavinaye pabbajito samāno kusīto vihareyyaṃ pamatto, na metaṃ assa patirūpan’ti.
segments.en: Now that I’ve gone forth in this well explained teaching and training, it would not be appropriate for me to live lazy and heedless.’
Then they reflect:

segments.pli: ‘āraddhaṃ kho pana me vīriyaṃ bhavissati asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggan’ti.
segments.en: ‘My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be immersed in samādhi.’

segments.pli: So dhammaṃyeva adhipatiṃ karitvā akusalaṃ pajahati, kusalaṃ bhāveti, sāvajjaṃ pajahati, anavajjaṃ bhāveti, suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharati.
segments.en: Putting the teaching in charge, they give up the unskillful and develop the skillful, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.
This is called putting the teaching in charge.
These are the three things to put in charge.
There’s no privacy in the world,
for someone who does bad deeds.
You’ll know for yourself,
whether you’ve lied or told the truth.
When you witness your good self,
you despise it;
while you disguise
your bad self inside yourself.
The gods and the Realized One see
the fool who lives unjustly in the world.
So with yourself in charge, live mindfully;
with the world in charge, be alert and practice absorption;
with the teaching in charge, live in line with that teaching:
a sage who tries for the truth doesn’t deteriorate.
Māra’s destroyed; the terminator’s overcome:
one who strives reaches the end of rebirth.
Poised, clever, knowing the world—
that sage identifies with nothing at all.”
